content.description:
Continue from "before dark" into the unknown. Follow a blue streak to a bulge. Crimp hard and continue to gain the anchors. Quite the pump can be had climbing this long route.

24 bolts

A good warm up for what is to come. Climb First light to the no hands rest and trend right. Good burly moves on steep jugs.

11 bolts

As Per Evan Hau's Description:

"New one at Planet X. Cobalt Gecko. Around 14c. I've fallen in love with these slightly off vertical routes lately. Just to the right of Iron Butterfly. The route has been looked at previously but I finished up the bolting and rejigged it about a month ago. Took me awhile to figure out a sequence through it that ended up being super cool!"

Next to Iron Butterfly (Right)
Bolts

Two distinct cruxes with tricky face climbing and powerful moves

15 bolts to the chains

Veer Left from Kurrgo into the steep corner. The climbing gets increasingly difficult the higher you get. A boulder problem guards the chains.

Left side
bolts

Climb to a no hands rest. Then boulder on fun holds all the way up. Good route.

11 bolts to chains

Some would call this the best 13d in the rockies. It is a power-endurance route for those who can muster it!

18 bolts to the chains

Continue above John Doe. A bouldery crux is followed by easier yet sustained climbing. Spectacular!

left side
bolts

Start the route on a short left facing dihedral near a tree. Crimping will get you to the top. A good rest can be found mid-way

16 bolts to chains

Next to a stump. 11c climbing until the break, then get ready to rumble. The 'Move' is a shoulder intensive iron cross type move.

13 bolts to chains

Not sure about the route as I don't know anyone who's been on it. Looks really hard. Megos or Sonnie can spray you down if you come to Canmore and are looking to get on this thing.

Furthest to the left. Looks impossible. Good luck!
Bolts to anchor

Start in front of a hole. Hard and sequence driven. A tough onsight.

6 bolts to anchor

From sendage: 
  
 One of the best 5.14a's in the Bow Valley. This Test piece will make you fight, scream, and sweat for days on end.  
 Start up a tricky runout slab for about 15 meters. This slab may never feel easier so get used to it. Then you move into the meat of the climb. The main climb starts with a very thugy intro with lots of big moves and blocky underclings. Then you move into a very powerful and runout crux, get through that, grab a bad shake and a low clip from an ok pinch and a crumbling crimp, then proceed to finish the route on some very pumpy and exposed moves. Mantle out of a roof into a mini corner to clip the chains.  
 Have fun!

18 bolts to anchor

From Evan's Sendage post:

"Takes the overhanging blank looking section between Sticky Buns and The Illusionist. I had wondered if this part of the wall would go years ago but never took a closer look until this year. Turns out there are holds and with some intricate beta, actually not that hard! Fun times bolting with Josh Brennan and we even got a cool 11c intro pitch out of it too!"

Between Sticky Buns and The Illusionist 
16 Bolts

Technical climbing to overhanging goodness. Very good and great for the grade.

16 bolts to the chains.

Climb the grey streaks and trend right. Finish on the midway anchor for The Illusionist.

6 bolts to chains

A little play on the two movies that came out about magic. Evan Hau describes it in Gripped magazine V17.03, 06/07 2015: 
  
 "The route can also be broken into 3 sections in reference to the movie: an easy intro slab (the pledge), a V13 crux (the turn), and a V9/10 exit crux (the prestige). The route features tufa textured blocky holds and technical movement which is typical for Planet X." 
  
 from sendage:  
  
 "After some time wandering around looking for the perfect project, this is the line that caught my attention and rekindled the psych. A powerful V13 crux leads to a perfect jug right before an amazing final roof encounter"

Adjacent line to the Illusionist and marked as a project on the picture. #10
bolts

Start on Shooting star and move towards fudge packer. A mix of both gives a midway grade. Popular and a must-do for those climbing at this grade

18 bolts to chains

Continuous and pumpy. Continually hard with no hard moves for the grade. Keep moving! 
  
 A hard, initial boulder problem follows 10+ climbing until the first anchor to a no hands rest. There you meet the first boulder problem which goes to underclings, a clipping crimp and a step up into a right hand block. 
  
 Easier climbing gets you to a shake out rest (good on the left side) which follows to a huck to the top rail jug. Hand traverse out to a rest and go straight up to a crimp. Another bulge pull over move (hard) gets you to another good rest and a set up for the final crux. Obvious moves get thin to a sloper out right and you pull over on pockets. Clip the chains and you're done.

17 bolts to anchor

11c climbing to the first set of anchors.  
  
 Breathe, and hurdle yourself into a boulder problem. The boulder problem involves a hard right hand sloper/micro crimp that goes to a left facing sidepull. Compression is king.

15 bolts to chains

Scramble to a high first/second bolt and pull up onto sandy ledge. Techy climbing leads you through a bulge into vert and then restful slab before you hit a section of super jugs where the wall kicks back again. 

Zig zag across the bolt line on super jugs to the top, except for that one spot where there are chalk stains on holds that aren't super jugs!



Towards the right end of the wall, look for about 5 m of 4th class/low 5th climbing to a ledge and a 2 m shield feature. There are a 2 bolt lines that go over this feature, Tickle My Fritter is the left bolt line. The first two bolts are relatively close, the second bolt being maybe 1.5 m up and left of the first. 


~16 bolts, rings with biners

Start the same as the hot gates but from the rest continue straight instead of trending left. Get a hold on the pump and fight to the anchors.

17 bolts to the chains

Planet Ex? Planet 10? Who cares? this incredible place is home to some of the hardest routes in Alberta.

If you want to crush some incredible lines in Cougar Canyon, this is the place to do it. This area was featured in a short by Jonathan Siegrist

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uZAFsFkdqwE

He describes it as being an area that has no holds and is based on compression. I think he may be correct about this description.

Multiple Open 5.14 projects, a half dozen 5.13 routes and some good lower grades make this a sure place to crush some incredible climbing during the summer. Shade all day and rain proof make it perfect for summers.
